"It's time!" one of the villagers say.

Anna grabs a pair of mirrors from the carriage, handing it to her and she uses them to read the writings tattooed across her body. Her tongue is strange and harsh, made even stranger by the writings she reads.

Orut steps forward, as Sir Redmond draws his sword.

"Oh, my poor, poor dear..." he says, grinning. "You gift me with this act and the ending of my duty."

The villagers begin to convulse as their bodies mutate. Eyes turn entirely black, teeth sharpen to like knives, claws grow forth as they turn into horrid beasts, laughing and chanting a single word.


"Kill!"

page 1089:
Alone on a Beach


You sit in a wooden armchair on the porch of your new grand manor, staring down at the long grey beach as rain pours, tapping against the porch roof.


"Couldn't it have been sunny for a moment like this?" Dikiz complains.


"Fuck it, it's fine," you say.


You sit there, a bottle of cider in your hands. Mira, Dikiz, Tilia and Orut are around you, conversing.


"So, what are your plans?" you ask.


Dikiz frowns, looking down.


"Umm... I guess my tale's kind of come to an end," she says. "I'm old as fuck."


"Is your time up?" you ask. 


"I have a little time left," Dikiz says. "I have a few plans. I want to return back to what's left of my tribe. I might still be able to breed, and if not I can always teach of our grand adventures."


"I'll miss you, cockroach," Mira says.


"Ah, don't make this depressing," Dikiz chides.


"What about you two?" you say, turning to Tilia and Orut.


"We're heading back to the Grove."


"You'll visit me some times, yes?"


"Of course, Tilia nods, as Orut grunts.


"Well then," you say finally. "I guess this is it."


"It is," Dikiz nods. "It's been a pleasure to be with all of you."


"And you," you nod, smiling.


"Goodbye," Dikiz says.


"Goodbye," Tilia says, as Orut grunts.


"Bye, guys."


With that, they turn and begin walking off, leaving you and Mira.


"So, what happens now?" you ask.


"Honestly?" Mira asks, sighing. "I love you, Ritz. I don't know if I've ever said it, but I do. But I can't do this. I can't be a queen, stuck here. I can never be a good wife or a good mother. I think it's time we call this thing to a close."


"Where will you go?"


I'll use my abundance of wealth to get passage on some ship heading West. The freedom of exploration! By the stars, that'll be amazing!"


"If that's what you tihnk is best."


Mira leans in, wrapping her arms around you, kissing you. Her lips linger, but only for a moment.


"I'll see you," she says, smiling. 


"Bye, Mira," you say.


"Goodbye, Ritz."


You watch the only person you ever loved walks out of your life. You pause, looking up at the ceiling, wondering how long until those things show up, if ever.


It doesn't matter, you decide. You'll just have to enjoy life as much as you can, with or without Mira.


With that, the only girl you've ever loved walks away, before looking up at rainy sky, wondering how you'll survive without her. You'll just have to enjoy life as much as you can. You will, you think.


Hey, this is the joys of retirement.

"Alright, I have no more questions," you say.


"OK, cool," Cotter says. "I'm going to head to sleep. I'll see you in the morning. We'll give each other hand with the work load, yeah?"

You smile, nodding, before Cotter walks off to his "spot" in the cage.  You sigh, finding a spot in the corner where you shove a Ratling with crippled legs out of the way and slump down against the bars, staring aimlessly at the sky. After about an hour, with the sky turning dark, a centaur rides up to check on you, a burning torch that illuminates the long, stalky grass in his hands. He peers through the bars, staring at all of you, before trotting off. You sigh, but dont react. However, as soon as you see that light extinguished as the centaur no doubt settles in for the night, a new face appears from the darkness, pressing against the bars.


Hello, little rats, Mira whispers. Stay quiet, would you?

Which of you accompanied the paladin? she asks.


You cautiously raise your hand, as she smiles.


Perfect, youre still alive. I need help, and youre the least heavily guarded. Everyone but him, up against the back of the cage! Mira says, aggressive but quiet.


The rats comply, pressing themselves against the back of the cage. Mira draws her sword, fumbling to unlock the cage with her free hand, before swinging it open. You step out, and she closes and locks it again.


What do you want?


I pledged my life to follow Steven the Fairs writing. In it, he said some day a hero will arrive, and it will be our duty to pass on his writings.


How do you know thats us? you ask.


Not us. The human boy. Eyes like the sky, hair like gold, a scar on his wrist. The Great Chieftain refuses to listen, but Im getting you out of here. We need to get the Raaz next. Lower halves? you frown, confused.


Mira pauses, looking to see if youre serious, before sighing.


Really, genius? Can you seriously not tell what Im referring to, she says, flicking her tail for emphasis.


Oh, you say, embarrassed.


Alright, lets go, she says. Stay quiet.


You nod, and follow her as you creep through the grass towards one of the tents. A centaur lies outside, his equine legs folded up as his body lies on them, a spear on the ground next to him. He seems fast asleep.


Damn, Mira says. What a pathetic example of a centaur. Come on, lets get past him. Grab his spear, first. Then, finish the idiot off for his shitty abilities in staying awake. Or spare him. Seems like your choicell be interesting enough to tell me whether youre as stupid as I thought you were.
page 282:
You creep forward, grabbing the spear lying there by the shaft, lifting it into the air. You stare at the loudly snoring centaur, wondering how the fuck he's so fast asleep.


"Weak," Mira mutters, spitting on the goon but sparing him.


Mira trots into the tent. You sigh, walking in after her. You push the tent flap out of your way, walking inside. Suddenly, a hooded figure leaps onto Mira as she yells in surprise. The figure, presumably Dikiz, jabs a dagger into Mira's back as she screams in pain, bucking quickly and sending Dikiz flying to the ground. Dikiz rolls and slashing at her fore leg. Mira kicks, her hoof slamming into Dikiz head and knocking her back.


"Damn it, you stupid cunt!" she says, snarling. "This was a rescue mission!"


Dikiz pauses, spotting you. She backs away in surprise, looking confused.


"Ritz? What are you doing here?" she asks.


"We're here to get you out of here," you explain.


"Oh," Dikiz says, dropping her dagger. "Sorry."


"Eat my cunt, you fucking bitch! Rat boy, find me some bandages, would you?"


You pause, looking around. It seems while you got stuck in a cage, Dikiz was trapped in a palace. The large, spacious tent has a large bed, a wardrobe, a large mirror and several other luxuries.


"Fucking Cestode! Why the hell is Dikiz being treated like this?"


"Will that help you find something to bandage me up?" Mira says. "Get searching, you little shit."


"Take it easy!" you say, cutting a strip of bed cloth free and handing it to her.


"Sorry, whiskers. I'm a bit pissed off today. I feel like I got stabbed in the back and the leg by a cockroach who was too stupid to realize what I was doing," she says, wrapping the strip of cloth around her stomach to bandage her wound. "We have good trading relationships with the Raaz, so we keep their prisoners treated very well to keep that relationship up. If we lose them as a partner we have nothing else."


"Where'd you even get a knife in here?" you ask Dikiz.


"Oh, the flowers in the vase are poisonous. I pressed them into an oil and poured it into the wine."


"Flowers and wine? Fuck, you shoved me in a cage filled with dudes covered in piss!" you say.


"The guards wanted to tie you to the back of them and go for a sprint across the desert," Mira says.


"Well anyway, I offered the wine to the guard and knocked him out. I heard you guys coming so I grabbed his knife and hid. Not the best security measures, leaving those flowers in here."


"Well see, we didn't actually know that you were such a flaming faggot that you knew what flowers did what," Mira says. "Fuck, your kind dwell in deserts for fuck's sake."


"Books," Mira shrugs. "I'm sorry for stabbing you."


Mira reaches her arm around, gently dipping her finger into the wound and covering it with flood, which she then flicked at Dikiz.


"Yeah, that apology healed the wound. Te-fucking-rrific. Let's go."


Mira turns as she begins to trot out of the tent, and you walk after her. You leave the tent, stepping past the unconscious guard.


"Pathetic. I thought he fell asleep on guard," Mira says. "Instead, he accepted wine from a prisoner. Either way he was a weak fool who deserved to die."


"He doesn't need to die. He won't wake up for hours," Dikiz says.


"You're as much as a coward as Whiskers. If he wakes up and alerts the guards, thank him. Now, let's go!"


You continue following Mira through the camp, soon arriving at an opening among the tents under a tarp suspended by several poles. About two dozen humans are there, chained to large stakes in the ground. They're all asleep. A pair of centaurs lazily stand on guard, mostly fiddling with their swords.


"Play along," Mira says, grabbing your spear and tossing it on the ground a few feet away, before putting one of each of her two sword's to both you and Dikiz's throat. 


Mira lets out a loud whistle, catching the pair's attention. The centaurs trot over, both quickly smacking their fist into their chests. They grunt in response, and the pair begin having a brief conversation. They talk briefly, before the two centaurs walk forward. One of them grabs you by the scruff of your neck, lifting you up to stare in your eye. The other slams the flat of her blade into Dikiz's head, grabbing her. They begin dragging you off back to your respective prisons, leaving Mira to the guard the prisoners. You wonder if she's turned you in, sacrificed you both to give her the chance to save Flynn. The centaur drags you close to your spear, within grabbing distance.
page 1151:
Love Triumphs


You sit in a wooden armchair on the porch of your new grand manor, staring down at the long grey beach as rain pours, tapping against the porch roof.


"Couldn't it have been sunny for a moment like this?" Dikiz complains.


"Fuck it, it's fine," you say.


You sit there, a bottle of cider in your hands. Mira, Dikiz, Tilia and Orut are around you, conversing.


"Well hey, this worked out pretty well," you say.


"Yeah, as good as it was going for us," Mira says.


"So, what are your plans?" you ask.


"Fuck it, I'm appreciating my freedom. I'll use my abundance of wealth to get passage on some ship heading West. The freedom of exploration! By the stars, that'll be amazing! What about Flower Power and the giant?"


"We're heading back to the Grove," Tilia says. "We get to keep Bucket, right?"


"Sure. You'll visit me and Dikiz some times, yes?" you ask.


"Of course, Tilia nods, as Orut grunts. "So you two are staying together?"


You look at Dikiz, who puts a hand around your shoulder.


"Of course," she says.


"Perfect," you smile, before looking at your friends. "I guess this is it."


"It is," Dikiz nods. "It's been a pleasure to be with all of you."


"Definitely," you nod.


"Let's cut the goodbyes short. We said 'em at the mountain," Mira says. "Goodbye, Ritz and Dikiz."


"Goodbye," Dikiz says.


"Goodbye," Tilia says, as Orut grunts.

You laugh, before silencing her with a kiss to her mandibles. You lean back, looking up at the rainy sky with a grin on your face.


Ah, love. What a wonderful thing.

"It's not what it looks like!" you shout.


"Explain!" a guard snarls.


"We're the companions of this wounded man, a paladin!" you say.

"Drop your weapons, centaur!" a guard yells.


"Fuck off!" Mira spits.


"Mira!" you shout.


Mira sighs, before throwing down her weapons.


"Good! Someone check the paladin for the brand! Jacobson, do it!"


One of the guards edges forward, lifting up Redmond's arm to reveal an eagle-shaped brand. 


"He's a paladin," the guard yells.


Redmond groans, and begins to mutter something.


"What?" the guard asks, leaning in. 


Redmond grabs the guard, twisting him around and drawing his knife, pressing it to the guard's left. The guards all raise their spears, as Redmond sighs.


"If one of you could tell me where the fuck I am and what's going on, I would appreciate it," Redmond rasps.


The Captain lowers his spear, raising his hands.


"Look, Sir Paladin, we have no issue with you! We were only investigating if you had been attacked and kidnapped by this group."


Sir Redmond releases the guard, who stumbles forward out of his grasp.


"They're with me. As a paladin, I...!" Redmond says, before passing and collapsing off his horse. 


"He needs a doctor!" you say frantically.


"We have a traveling alchemist passing through town. Cheung, Faust, get the paladin."


Two guards rush forward, grabbing Redmond and lifting him into the air. They carry him off, and Scampers scampers after them. You move quickly through the town to a caravan at the edge of town. You climb over Scampers and follow Redmond as he's dragged inside.


"How the fuck do I go in there?" Mira complains loudly.


"Wait outside!" Dikiz says as she rushes inside. 


Inside, a young woman mixes potions, turning around. You pause, staring at her. She's very beautiful, with pale skin and long, ebony black hair. Her eyes and wide and shockingly blue.


"Ah look, a new patient," she says.


She grabs a pair of gloves, slipping them on and walks forward, grabbing Redmond and leading him to a seat.


"What's the ailment?" she asks.


"He's been poisoned with Manasa Grass Oil," you say.


You watch as the alchemist begins searching through her potions and what she has at her disposal, frowning. 


"It's... I'll be honest, it's not optimistic."


She grabs a book, flicking through it before stopping on a page, frowning.


"Ah... it appears I don't have what's needed to help him."


"Where do we get it?" the captain asks.


"Deep within the grove. At least a day's journey into it."


"How far are we from the grove?"


"At least a day," the Captain says.


"Hmm... we'll last about two, maybe three days."


"I'll send a rider to gather what you need," the Captain says.


"No, it'll be a two day journey either way. He won't last that. You'd need to take him with you and make the potion there."


"What can we do?" Flynn asks. "Can you help us?"


Flynn stares into the Alchemist's eyes as they go quiet.


"Hey Flynn, remember that old guy who mentored us? Reddington or something? Yeah, he's dying in front of us."


"I could come with you to the grove to make the potion," the Alchemist says. "I'm due a trip there to refresh my stock. It would take about three days with the carriage, but we could make it."


"Dikiz, Ritz, go restock on supplies," Flynn says, pulling a satchel of golden coins from his satchel and handing it to you. "I'll deal with the alchemist."


"It's Anna," the alchemist says. "Take guards with you so the shopkeepers serve you.


"Um... OK," Dikiz says.


"Yeah, let's go," you say, walking outside.


You head alongside Dikiz, Mira and the Captain as the town guards disperse to continue their regular duties, towards the general store.


"So what did they say?" Mira asks. "Are we slitting his throat?"


"No! Hell, take it easy!" Dikiz says.


"We need to head to the Grove to get the herbs and ingredients ready to cure him," you say.


"Oh for fuck's sake! We don't need a detour! Hang on, don't we need a nature spirit for the plan?"


"We do," you say.


"Oh, maybe this won't be a waste of time. We head to the grove, kidnap a nature spirit, find whatever herbs, maybe bury the paladin, then head off towards the mountains for that Titan blood."


"You're right," you say. "Hey, Dikiz? I have a question about social shit."


"Not my specialty, but fire," Dikiz says.


"Do you think there was anything going on between that Alchemist and Flynn?"


"What do you mean "going on"? Like, they almost started mating in front of us."


"Oh great. So we basically just got a random fuck buddy for Flynn."


"Jealous?" Mira laughs.


"Let's go shopping," you say.


You resupply on everything you need, and soon arrive back at the caravan, where Flynn and Anna are talking.


"Anna is going to accompany us on our quest in exchange for a note of pardons from Paladin Redmond to allow her to import certain illegal potions and herbs," Flynn says.


"Great," you say. "So the party's growing by one."


"We need to go," you say.


"We do," Anna says.


"Let's get riding then," Mira says. 


You turn to the Captain, who stares at you.


"Thanks for your help," you say.


"My pleasure, ratling. You're a credit to your species. As are your centaur and Raaz friend."


"Hurry the fuck up, shit for brains!" Mira yells, as the carriage begins to pull away. 


"Maybe just teh Raaz and you," the Captain says.

"What the fuck?" you say.


"Do you like it? This universe is a depressing one, isn't it? So grimdark. Eh, no bother."

"What? Aren't you happy to see your old pal Mr Chinkrinkski?"


"Mister... who?"


The Tourist pauses, blinking slowly.


"Oh yes, I used the name the Tourist last time, didn't I? My mistake. I have so many names." 


"Where am I? What the fuck did you do to me?!" you shout, standing up.


You go to draw your sword, before pausing.


"Oh good, you're learning!" the Tourist grins.  "I was... "talking", to translate it as best I can, to an old friend, and we brought up Crexiciliatanian's little game. He thought you'd be an interesting client." 


"What the fuck are you talking about?" you ask.


"I have a merchant I'd like to talk to. The Merchant can be his name. He'd like to trade with you. He rarely does with such mortals, but you've become of interest to me."


The entire world goes black, before being brightened by a single light from a candle. The candle sits on a table, at which a hooded figure sits behind. His face is obscured by shadows, and you can vaguely make out rat-like features. He waves a hand, as a seat appears in front of the table. 


"Well, I'll leave you two to talk. It'll definitely be interesting to see what happens with the rat, won't it?" the Tourist says. "Oh yes, before I go, here."


The Tourist places down a gold coin on the table, smiling.


"Thanks," you say, examining it. "This is just a single Throne. I have hundreds of these at camp."


"It's representative of something your mind couldn't really comprehend. Just enjoy it."


You turn, staring at the Merchant. 


"Hello," he says in a dark voice with a foreign tinge. "You wish to trade, yes?"


You pause, before nodding. You pick up the coin, staring at it.


"What can you give me for this?" you ask. 


"Many things. What is it you want?"


"A sword that can kill anything," you say.


The merchant stares at you, sighing.


"Such  a thing would be easy to create, but you both don't have enough money for it. That would be very damaging to poor Crexiciliatanian. Let me find a few things worth worth what you have."


The Merchant opens his hands, and a black light appears in it, dancing around.


"Are you a rat? Like me?" you ask.


"No. This form is only to calm you. The offer I have is simple. Knowledge versus power versus happiness."


The Merchant puts his hand on the table, sliding it along as three cards appear. He flips them, revealing an image of a man reading a book wearing glasses, an image of strong knight wielding a sword and an image of a grinning man dancing with a goblet of wine in his hands.


"What's knowledge?"


"You're curious about me, aren't you? That coin will buy you a glance at my true form, if you'd like. I'll even throw in my name, if you want."


"And the power?"


"Nothing over the top. There are an infinite amount of universes, Ritz," the Merchant says, a syringe filled with a black, ink like substance inside it. "I have a universe in mind. Almost the exact same as yours, with the unfortunate change that you were a stillborn."


You pause, staring at him in confusion.


"Another me that died?"


"Exactly, one that never got to be. A shadow of you. His essence is inside here. With a brief injection, I can give you him."


"What the fuck are you talking about?"


"It should give you quite a few powers. That's really all you need to understand."


"And the joy?" 


"You're a useless pawn in your world of no importance. I have a wondrous location I could transport you to, free of your world, where your existence would be pure, unending joy. You'd leave your own universe behind, of course, but so is so."


You stare at him, mulling over the choice.

Oak, Silver, Ash, Dodger, Buttercup and Apples all happily chew grass and relax in the sunshine. Khepri is hiding in the shadows, chewing on the bug-infested roots of one of the trees. Scampers chews on fruit that has fallen from one of the trees. Anna's carriage sits there, so you get about to attaching her horses to it.


After about half an hour of pleading, begging and screaming, you manage to get them hooked up there, although there's a few new bruises covering you. Silver and Ash are more used to you, or perhaps you're just more used to where they tend to kick for, because you manage to get their saddles on fairly easily. Khepri is a doll, allowing you to saddle it up while it makes a noise that you've began to identify as purring rather than hissing. Scampers is last, and you saddle him up and climb onto him, rubbing his fur.


"Come on, let's go," you say.


Scampers begin to run along the field as you run back to the rest of the village. Mira's been released from her vine prison, as about a dozen Satyrs aim their pikes at her nervously. 


"Pikes down, fuckers. If I wanted to I could kill every fucking one of you, cut off your heads and shit down your throats."


"You don't even have weapons!" one of the Satyrs says.


"Oh, you don't even want to know what I'd do to you all if I had my swords," Mira grins.


The rest of your party arrives, strolling along towards the steeds.


"Tilia, is it?" Dikiz asks, as the Nymph appears, carrying a burlap bag.


"Please, call me Tilly."


"Where's your steed?" you ask.


"The Free Folk of the Grove don't enslave animals as steeds. We simply ask the creatures of the forest for a ride."


You arrive in the field as the group begins mounting their steeds. 


"Do you want a lift in the carriage, Tilia?" Anna asks.


"No, I'll ask the wind for a lift, and the wind will ask the forest, and the forest will provide," Tilia says.


"Are you high, drunk or fucking insane?" Mira says incredulously.


Tilly lets out a loud whistle like a bird singing, before pausing.


"We need to go," Redmond says. "Get on the carriage, Tilia, and...!"


Suddenly, a massive stag bursts forward from the trees, running up to Tilly. It halts, lowering its head as Tilly kisses it gently on the forehead. 


"Thank you for your service, my friend," she says, before climbing onto its back. "Shall we go?"


"Fucking tree cunt," Mira sighs, before spitting on the ground. 


"I've found myself truly blessed with such company," Tilly says, as you begin riding off.
page 323:
"Power," you answer, sliding the coin across the table.


The Merchant takes the coin, lifting it to its face to sniff it, before tossing it back into its mouth and swallowing. 


"Show me your arm," it says.


You hold out your arm and it grabs it, jabbing the needle into it and pressing down on the plunging. You grown, letting out a sigh.


"Here you are, child," it says.


The candle brightens, illuminating the stone room you're it. An apple appears on the table.


"Look to your right," the Merchant says.


You turn your head, seeing your shadow sitting on the stone, next to the shadow of the apple.


"Focus on grabbing the apple, but don't," the Merchant advises. 


You focus on the apple, imaging picking it up with your mind.


"Don't look at the apple. Look at the shadow of it," the Merchant says.


You turn, staring at the shadow. Suddenly, your shadow moves, leaning forward. Your shadow moves independently, grabbing the shadow of the apple and holding it in the air. You freeze, watching the apple rising into the air, floating there as the shadow holds it. The shadow holds it out so that it floats directly in front of you. You lean forward, grabbing it. Your shadow bows, before returning to its position of mimicking you.


"Wondrous, isn't it? It only works in low light, but it should be helpful," the Merchant says. " A good trade. Now, I'll leave you back to where you were."


The Merchant claps his hands, and the candle goes out, leaving you in total darkness.


"Close your eyes," he whispers.


You follow his orders.


"Now, open."
page 565:
It's so fucking cold.


The party trudges up the mountain, slowly heading to the nearby ogre raiding camp. It's been a long few days of travel, but you've made it here. Tilly went through several steeds that are "assisting" her in her travel, including deer, wild stallions and mares and at this point, a massive Ram that she's sitting on.


"Fuck! I miss my sunny plains! I miss warmth! I can't feel my fucking cunt!" Mira yells into the cold air, wrapping herself in further leathers and furs in the first time she's wore clothes. 


"I think I'm dead," the muffled voice of the massive bundle of blankets and furs that you believe Dikiz to be at the center of. "Raaz live in deserts."


"We'll be at the camp soon," Redmond says. 


Bucket, who is covered in fur to keep him warm, lets out a grunting noise, as Tillia hushes him.


"What exactly is our plan when we get there?" Flynn asks.


"We recruit their chieftain," Redmond says.


"That's really more of a goal," Anna points out.


"Ogres are easily negotiated with, as they understand shockingly little. Sure, on a raid they're too focused on slaughter to be negotiated with, but if we catch them by surprise they'll be confused enough that we can easily negotiate with them."


"That doesn't seem logical," Tilly says. "Is there a back-up plan?"


"We carve our way out of their and retreat down the mountain," Redmond says.


Redmond pauses, staring off into the distance. He points to a distant mountain nearer to civilization. 


"Do you see that? That little mountain over there?"


A chorus of affirmative responses come back, one of them yours.


"Mol'Chu is there, hidden deep in the mountain. Once we get the ogre, we head there and finish this. Dikiz, you have the Ninth Key, yes?"


"No, I left it at the the centaur camp," Dikiz says sarcastically. "Obviously I Still have it."


"Then we head there next."


Dikiz says something, although thanks to the many layers of cloth covering her, you don't understand her.


"What?" you ask.


"I see lights!" she says more clearly, pointing up to vague lights in the difference.


You ride on with renewed hope at an end to the cold, soon getting close enough to see. The ogre camp is closer to a fortress, seeing as their massive strength has allowed them to carry massive tree trunks up to this altitude to build a massive wooden wall.


You continue heading up to the frosted home of the Ogre people, riding on with renewed vigour. You can make out massive mammoth and ogre skulls mounted on the largest of tree trunks, with more humanoid skulls of your partys kind mounting the smaller ones. Massive bronze braziers light up the camp and no doubt flood the occupants with warmth. From the smell that fills the smoke they spew forth, the ogres seem to be using them to cook. The lack of massive, burly Ogres mounting the walls assures you that theres no patrols or look-outs. It seems the Ogres are too stupid to expect an attack, or perhaps you and your allies are just the only ones stupid enough to climb a mountain to attack the fortress of a clan of Ogres. Either way, you have options here.


What do we do? Do we knock on the door, or? Flynn asks.


We have two options. We can sneak in so that we can skip having to negotiate our way past a tribe of savage ogres, or we can simply knock on the front door and see where our luck carries us.


What about fighting? Mira asks. Do we need the Ogre to be willing? If not, we could easily wipe out the tribe barring him and drop a boulder on his skull.


We do need him to be willing, Redmond says. So, sneak or talk. Shall we put it to a vote? Who wants to sneak?


A nervous Tilly, a terrified Anna and the blanket creature that consumed Dikiz raises their hands. On the other side, Redmond, Flynn and surprisingly Mira raise their hands.


Mira, you dont seem to be the sneaky type.


Oh, talking wont work. Well go to the gates, make our presence known, theyll attack, then we do my plan, Mira says.


Ritz, break the vote, Redmond demands.

page 567:
Lets try sneaking. I don't want to have to talk my way past," you say. 


Cant Tilia just make the trees grow up and destroy their walls or something? Flynn asks.


I can make trees grow many times at their rate. That still doesnt even amount to something that can be seen by the human eye except over a long period of time unless I have the Grove helping me. Theres not even any life up here except the hardiest of creatures like my ally brother ram here.


Tilia rubs her ram steeds neck as it bows its head. You leave, dismounting your steeds and tying them up to a peg stuck into the frozen earth, before you begin sneaking around the camp. You reach the wall, circling slowly around, looking for an opening. Finally, you see a crack in the wall, stepping through the gap and moving inside. The group of you move through, before Mira pauses.


"There's no way I'm fitting through there," she says.


"Circle around back. We might need you to cause a distraction," you say.


You move into the camp, finding yourself in the center of the cooking area. Several iron pots filled with boiling meat sit there, a delicious smell drifting into you. You frown, realizing the meat is most likely human.


Suddenly, an ogre walks forward with a massive wooden spoon, whistling to himself. He sticks his massive wooden spoon in the pot, beginning to stir as he hums to himself. Suddenly he pauses, lifting up the spoon and sniffing it. He pauses, turning around to stare at you all.


"Attack! Attack!" he roars.


Suddenly, Ogres begin to appear, frantically appearing from their huts lugging massive clubs, war-hammers and battle-axes as they charge forward.


"Fuck! Fight!" Redmond yells.


You jab forward, slashing at their knees and ducking under a club swing. You narrowly avoid a war-hammer, before there's an ear splitting roar.


"Enough!" a massive figure screams.


A massive, bulky figure, completely naked except for a pair of iron arm bracelets with skulls hanging from them, wielding a massive steel war-hammer. The other ogres immediately begin backpedaling and dropping their weapons.


"I'm the boss! Big boss Orut Skull-Taker!" he shouts. "You remember my name!"


The Chieftain strolls forward, his eyes narrowing as he stares at you. He strolls forward, hefting his war-hammer over his shoulder. He pauses, staring at you.


"Human, human, human, human, ratling..."


"Actually, I'm not a huma..." Tilly begins to say, before Redmond hushes her. 


"... bug, human," he says. "Bugs aren't tasty. Go away."


Orut pauses, staring at Mira in confusion.


"Human, where are your legs? Where's your horse's head?"


"It's all me, dumbass," Mira says.


Orut stares on in confusion. He reaches out, grabbing Mira by the torso and lifting her up, watching in shock as her equine lower body rises with it. He grins, laughing.


"Ha! I like you! I like you a lot! You're funny. I might not eat you! Wait, never ate you before? Do you taste good?"


"If you try to eat me, I'll cut my way out your asshole," Mira says, spitting on Orut's face.


"I like you. Keep you. Scare the bug away. Eat the rest," Orut demands.


"Wait!" Redmond says. "You don't even know why we're here! Aren't you curious?"


Orut stares blanky as if the word "curious" means nothing to him. Hell, with his vocabulary it probably doesn't.


"There's a threat that we need your help to destroy! A threat that'll wipe out your people!"


Orut pauses, thinking on this.


"No," he says, finally.


"What? No?" Redmond asks in confusion.


"No. Won't happen," Orut says. "I'm strong, I can kill anything."


"No! You can't kill it without our help!" Redmond says, pausing to think of of a suitable metaphor.

You open your eyes to stare up at the smiling face of the Tourist. You pause, looking up at a completely white sky, illuminated a massive black sun. 


"What the fuck?" you say.


"Do you like it? This universe is a depressing one, isn't it? So grimdark. Eh, no bother."


"You're back," you say simply, staring at him with a mixture of horror and confusion.


"What? Aren't you happy to see your old pal Mr Chinkrinkski?"


"Mister... who?"


The Tourist pauses, blinking slowly.


"Oh yes, I used the name the Tourist last time, didn't I? My mistake. I have so many names." 


"Where am I? What the fuck did you do to me?!" you shout, standing up.


You go to draw your sword, before pausing.


"Oh good, you're learning!" the Tourist grins.  "I was... "talking", to translate it as best I can, to an old friend, and we brought up Crexiciliatanian's little game. He thought you'd be an interesting client." 


"What the fuck are you talking about?" you ask.


"I have a merchant I'd like to talk to. The Merchant can be his name. He'd like to trade with you. He rarely does with such mortals, but you've become of interest to me."


The entire world goes black, before being brightened by a single light from a candle. The candle sits on a table, at which a hooded figure sits behind. His face is obscured by shadows, and you can vaguely make out rat-like features. He waves a hand, as a seat appears in front of the table. 


"Well, I'll leave you two to talk. It'll definitely be interesting to see what happens with the rat, won't it?" the Tourist says. "Oh yes, before I go, here."


The Tourist places down a gold coin on the table, smiling.


"Thanks," you say, examining it. "This is just a single Throne. I have hundreds of these at camp."


"It's representative of something your mind couldn't really comprehend. Just enjoy it."


You turn, staring at the Merchant. 


"Hello," he says in a dark voice with a foreign tinge. "You wish to trade, yes?"


You pause, before nodding. You pick up the coin, staring at it.


"What can you give me for this?" you ask. 


"Many things. What is it you want?"


"A sword that can kill anything," you say.


The merchant stares at you, sighing.


"Such  a thing would be easy to create, but you both don't have enough money for it. That would be very damaging to poor Crexiciliatanian. Let me find a few things worth worth what you have."


The Merchant opens his hands, and a black light appears in it, dancing around.


"Are you a rat? Like me?" you ask.


"No. This form is only to calm you. The offer I have is simple. Knowledge versus power versus happiness."


The Merchant puts his hand on the table, sliding it along as three cards appear. He flips them, revealing an image of a man reading a book wearing glasses, an image of strong knight wielding a sword and an image of a grinning man dancing with a goblet of wine in his hands.


"What's knowledge?"


"You're curious about me, aren't you? That coin will buy you a glance at my true form, if you'd like. I'll even throw in my name, if you want."


"And the power?"


"Nothing over the top. There are an infinite amount of universes, Ritz," the Merchant says, a syringe filled with a black, ink like substance inside it. "I have a universe in mind. Almost the exact same as yours, with the unfortunate change that you were a stillborn."


You pause, staring at him in confusion.


"Another me that died?"


"Exactly, one that never got to be. A shadow of you. His essence is inside here. With a brief injection, I can give you him."


"What the fuck are you talking about?"


"It should give you quite a few powers. That's really all you need to understand."


"And the joy?" 


"You're a useless pawn in your world of no importance. I have a wondrous location I could transport you to, free of your world, where your existence would be pure, unending joy. You'd leave your own universe behind, of course, but so is so."


You stare at him, mulling over the choice.

"We just butchered your people, including goddamn children, and this is what gets you angry? I don't even feel bad about killing you."

"Fucking Cestode! She's a slave?" one of the rats asks.


"She's being treated like royalty!" another complains.


"Hurry up!" Mira hisses.


You cut a long strip of cloth from the bed, handing it to her.


"Thanks. Sorry for bitching, Whiskers. I'm a bit pissed off today. "We have good trading relationships with the Raaz, so we keep their prisoners treated very well to keep that relationship up. If we lose them as a partner we have nothing else."


"Where'd you even get a knife in here?" you ask Dikiz.


"Oh, the flowers in the vase are poisonous. I pressed them into an oil and poured it into the wine."


"Flowers and wine? Fucking bug cunt. You're lucky I don't fuck...!" one of the rats bitches.


"Hey! Cool it before I cut off your dick and force it down your throat!" you spit.


"Sorry, boss," he says. 


"Well anyway, I offered the wine to the guard and knocked him out. I heard you guys coming so I grabbed his knife and hid. Not the best security measures, leaving those flowers in here."


"Well see, we didn't actually know that you were such a flaming faggot that you knew what flowers did what," Mira says. "Fuck, your kind dwell in deserts for fuck's sake."


"Books," Mira shrugs. "I'm sorry for stabbing you."


Mira reaches her arm around, gently dipping her finger into the wound and covering it with flood, which she then flicked at Dikiz.


"Yeah, that apology healed the wound. Te-fucking-rrific. Let's go."
